awd_titl_txt: TWC TTP: Small: Collaborative: Privacy-Preserving Data Collection and Access for IEEE 802.11s-Based Smart Grid Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The modernized Smart Grid (SG) is expected to enable several new applications such as dynamic pricing, demand response and fraud detection; however, collection of such fine-grained data raises privacy issues. This project aims to design and implement several novel mechanisms for securing data collection and communication in SG Advanced Metering Infrastructure applications while preserving user privacy when the data are to be accessed. The underlying communication infrastructure, namely Neighborhood Area Networks, is to be built with wireless mesh networks using the IEEE 802.11s, an IEEE 802.11 amendment for mesh networking. The project investigates user privacy preservation mechanisms using partially and fully homomorphic encryption during data collection in the Neighborhood Area Networks. For the collected data at the data repository, attribute-based access control mechanisms are studied. As part of these access control mechanisms, novel scalable key establishment and group key management schemes are investigated. A testbed consisting of IEEE 802.11 Linux routers is part of the project to assess the overhead of privacy mechanisms under quality of service constraints. 

The testbed will be a community resource for researchers, educators and students as well as utility companies interested in SG communications and privacy.  Ensuring practical user privacy solutions will increase the participation of customers in SG applications saving cost and energy. The testbed will be a great help to utilities, researchers and educators who work on SG communications. The software and technical manuals will be made available as open-source documents. New graduate courses on the Smart Grid will be introduced into the academic curriculum.

por.por_cntn:
The modernized smart grid is expected to enable several new applications such as dynamic pricing, demand response and fraud detection as a result of collecting real-time and fine-grained power consumption data. However, collection of such fine-grained data raises several privacy issues for the customers. For example, by analyzing the power usage data reported by a smart meter, one can easily figure out the residents’ basic daily activities, their presence/absence and religions, their genders and rough ages, etc. Such a privacy disclosure violates the laws in many countries for safety and security concerns. In this project, the PI intends to develop privacy-preserving schemes to secure the data collected by smart meters, the communications between smart meters and utility companies, and the smart meter readings stored in clouds.

 

Intellectual Merit: 

The PI at GWU mainly carried out the following research activities: i) developing a privacy-preserving fine-grained smart meter data collection scheme that can support billing at the utility company side; ii) designing an attribute-based signcryption scheme to secure multicast communications in smart grids; and iii) devising a verifiable access control scheme to secure the ciphertext smart meter data stored in clouds. This research endeavor yields the following results: i) a novel group signature scheme that does not require the signing keys to be updated for each signature calculation; ii) a secret token based scheme that can break the linkage between smart meter readings while allowing the utility company to compute the bills for each billing period; iii) a decryption procedure for the NTRU cryptosystem that overcomes the decryption failures of the original NTRU; iv) a verifiable access control scheme that supports the updates of access policies as well as the smart meter readings in ciphertext stored in clouds; v) a Ciphertext-Policy Attribute Based Signcryption scheme (CP_ABSC) that implements role-based access control while simultaneously providing encryption and signature services; and vi) a multicast scheme based on CP_ABSC that can secure the multicast messages to the destinations specified by a set of attributes in smart grids. One can see that the PI has tackled novel problems and achieved important results toward privacy-preserving fine-grained data collection, storage, and communications in smart grids.

 

Broader Impact: 

The project at GWU was carried out by the PI who is a female faculty and one PhD student, yielding one PhD thesis and a number of peer-reviewed publications. The PI has been organizing a weekly group seminar open to all graduate students focusing on privacy issues and the research findings have been integrated into the courses of wireless and mobile security and privacy-ware computing via course projects and lecture presentations. The proposed schemes can be easily adapted by utility companies to ensure user/data privacy and security in smart metering. The solutions that ensure practical user privacy can help increase the participation of customers in smart grid applications saving cost and energy. On the other hand, the proposed use of attribute-based access control, NTRU cryptosystem, group signature scheme, etc., can help promote more research on similar privacy-based problems in crowd sensing, cloud computing, and social networking.
